name: Adult Attachment Styles Assessment
description: Assessment of adult attachment patterns based on how you typically feel and behave in close relationships.
instructions: Think about your close relationships (romantic partners, close friends, family). Rate how much each statement describes your typical feelings and behaviors.

secure.name: Secure Attachment
secure.description: Comfortable with intimacy and independence. Views self and others positively.
growth_areas: Could benefit from setting clearer boundaries
secure.relationship_style: Forms stable, lasting relationships with good communication and mutual support.

anxious_preoccupied.name: Anxious-Preoccupied Attachment
anxious_preoccupied.description: Desires close relationships but worries about partner's feelings. Views others positively but self negatively.
growth_areas: Practice direct communication instead of seeking reassurance
anxious_preoccupied.relationship_style: Seeks closeness but may become clingy or demanding. Prone to relationship anxiety.

dismissive_avoidant.name: Dismissive-Avoidant Attachment
dismissive_avoidant.description: Values independence over relationships. Views self positively but others negatively.
growth_areas: Work on empathy and emotional attunement
dismissive_avoidant.relationship_style: Maintains emotional distance. May struggle with intimacy and commitment.

fearful_avoidant.name: Fearful-Avoidant (Disorganized) Attachment
fearful_avoidant.description: Wants close relationships but fears being hurt. Views both self and others negatively.
fearful_avoidant.relationship_style: Push-pull dynamic in relationships. Craves intimacy but fears abandonment or engulfment.

secure_with_secure.description: Highly compatible. Both partners are comfortable with intimacy and independence.
potential_challenges: Could benefit from more growth challenges
secure_with_secure.advice: Continue open communication and support each other's individual growth.

secure_with_anxious.description: Secure partner can provide stability for anxious partner's growth.
potential_challenges: Secure partner may not understand anxiety
secure_with_anxious.advice: Patient reassurance from secure partner. Anxious partner should work on self-soothing.

secure_with_avoidant.description: Secure partner can help avoidant partner become more comfortable with intimacy.
secure_with_avoidant.advice: Respect avoidant partner's need for space while encouraging gradual opening.

anxious_with_avoidant.description: Classic 'pursuer-distancer' dynamic. Can trigger each other's insecurities.
anxious_with_avoidant.advice: Both partners need individual work on attachment patterns. Professional support recommended.

anxious_with_anxious.description: High emotional intensity. Can be very supportive or very volatile.
anxious_with_anxious.advice: Focus on individual emotional regulation and maintaining separate identities.

avoidant_with_avoidant.description: Low conflict but potentially low intimacy and connection.
avoidant_with_avoidant.advice: Make intentional efforts to increase emotional intimacy and vulnerability.

secure: Consider couples counseling for major life transitions
